awd_titl_txt: Exploring Strong Field Molecular and Electron Dynamics, and Oxidation of Bio-Organic Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
H. Bernhard Schlegel of Wayne State University is supported by an award from the Theory, Models and Computational Methods program within the Chemistry Division for research to further our understanding of the way lasers reveal details about chemical reactions. The work supported is theoretical and computational in nature, but is being carried out in close collaboration with experimental scientists who are testing the predictions of these theories in laser laboratories. The investigations provide information on how light delivered in short, intense pulses can be used to follow minute details of atoms and molecules as chemical reactions are taking place. In a second portion of the project, the investigators are studying how damage to DNA by oxidizing species occurs at the molecular level. This process is thought to be at the core of a number of health problems, including cancer and aging. The work is promoting the progress of science by developing new tools and methods that will have application in many other areas of science. The work is also helping to train the next generation of scientists in projects that involve a high degree of collaboration between computational scientists and experimental scientists.

The research has three main categories: (1) a study of strong field molecular dynamics; (2) electron dynamics in strong fields; and (3) oxidation in bio-organic systems. In (1), the investigators are studying isomerization and fragmentation of molecules in intense mid-IR (infrared) laser fields using molecular dynamics calculations. In some cases that go beyond the Born-Oppenheimer approximation, the investigators are using Ehrenfest dynamics and extended Lagrangian dynamics. In (2), time-dependent Hartree-Fock, density functional and configuration interaction methods with real space complex absorbing potentials are being used to investigate electron dynamics and ionization processes in strong laser fields. Topics under investigation include angle-resolved ionization rates in conjugated molecules, electron dynamics in ions during and after ionization, and changes in ionization rates during isomerization and fragmentation reactions. In (3), oxidation of G-quadruplexes, guanine-lysine adduct formation during oxidative degradation of guanine, and oxidation of ascorbic acid are being investigated. Continuum solvation models with cavity scaling are being used to obtain reliable pKas, redox potentials and energetics along reaction paths.

por.por_cntn:
(a) Dynamics in Intense Laser Fields Strong field chemistry and attosecond science are rapidly growing areas in chemical physics. Intense laser pulses can strongly distort the electron density in a manner that cannot be treated by perturbation theory. Physicists in the field focus on atoms and diatomics; we are among a small group of chemists who are developing computational methods to simulate polyatomic systems under these extreme conditions. (i) To model electron dynamics during strong field ionization, we integrate the time-dependent Schrodinger equation using time-dependent configuration interaction and a complex absorbing potential (TDCI-CAP). The angular dependence of ionization by linearly polarized light can be interpreted in terms of the nodal structure of the highest occupied molecular orbitals. In turn, the angular dependence of ionization by circularly polarized light can be understood by averaging the results for linearly polarized light. (ii) For molecular dynamics in intense laser fields, we have studied isomerization and fragmentation of allene cation, and explored using a two pulse sequence to enhance specific dissociation channels in the strong field fragmentation of ClCHO+.. 

(b) DNA Oxidation and Bio-organic Oxidations (i) Oxidative damage to DNA can result in crosslinks, but these mechanisms are not well understood experimentally, and no computational studies were available to provide guidance. Our calculated pathways provide an explanation for product yields for guanine-lysine crosslinks induced by type I and type II photosensitizers and oxidation with sulfate radical anion, and for the ratios of 8oxoguanine to guanine-thymine crosslinks as a function of pH during oxidation by carbonate radical. (ii) Ascorbic acid is a key antioxidant; ascorbate radical disproportionates or reacts with other radicals, but reacts poorly with non-radical species. None of the existing calculations have examined the details of the disproportionation reaction. Our calculations revealed that disproportionation proceeds via dimerization and internal electron transfer followed by cyclization and dissociation to yield the fully reduced and fully oxidized bicyclic structures, and that radical scavenging by ascorbic acid proceeds in a similar fashion.

(c) pKa Calculations To explore reaction mechanisms in buffered solution (such as oxidative damage of DNA and ascorbic acid oxidation), we need to calculate the energy of different protonation and oxidation states on an equal footing, without resorting to thermodynamic cycles or linear regression to estimate pKa’s and redox potentials. Current implicit solvation models like SMD are satisfactory for direct calculation of protonation reactions yielding cations, but can have errors of 5-10 pKa units for deprotonations yielding anions. We found that when a few explicit water molecules are included in addition to implicit solvation, direct calculations of pKa’s for alcohols, phenols, hydroperoxides, thiols and selenols are in good agreement with experiment without the need for linear correlations.

(d) Optimization Almost all computational chemistry studies involve some sort of geometry optimization. As an alternative to the chain-of-states approach for reaction path optimization, we examined the minimization of the variational reaction path energy using a continuous representation of the path rather than using a set of points. We also prepared a larger test set of molecules for optimization and tested several improvements to geometry optimization.

(e) Collaborative Projects These projects are win-win ventures. We help our experimental colleagues by contributing solid theoretical treatments of their novel findings. Students in the group gain valuable computation abilities that broaden their expertise and strengthen their teamworking skills. For ruthenium complexes developed for photochemotherapy by Kodanko (WSU), we found an orbital explanation for the selective release of specific ligands after excitation. Our DFT calculations have contributed to the understanding of rectification in iron complexes studied by Verani (WSU). With Allen (WSU), we found an explanation for the extraordinary visible luminescence of europium aza-cryptate complexes.
